definition: Mao Sui (third century BC), who proverbially offered his services to the King of Chu 楚, see 毛遂自薦|毛遂自荐[Mao2 Sui4 zi4 jian4]

hair/feather/down/wool/mildew/mold/coarse or semifinished/young/raw/careless/unthinking/nervous/scared/(of currency) to devalue or depreciate/classifier for Chinese fractional monetary unit ( = 角[jiao3] , = one-tenth of a yuan or 10 fen 分[fen1])
surname Mao
to satisfy/to succeed/then/thereupon/finally/unexpectedly/to proceed/to reach
Mao Sui recommends himself (idiom); to offer one's services (in the style of Mao Sui offering his services to king of Chu 楚 of the Warring states)

sentences.english: I fully expected one of the women to volunteer6, as was usually the case.
sentences.chinese: 我满心指望像平常一样，某位女士能毛遂自荐。

sentences.english: A man called Mao Sui volunteered.
sentences.chinese: 有一个名叫毛遂的人，自告奋勇愿意同去。

sentences.english: He offers up his services to finish the operation.
sentences.chinese: 他毛遂自荐来完成这个行动计划。

sentences.english: It is a great pleasure for me to introduce myself to you here.
sentences.chinese: 我是如斯的快乐在这儿向人人作毛遂自荐。

sentences.english: Lord Ping Yuan felt there was some truth to Mao Sui's word, and reluctantly agreed to take him along to the negotiations.
sentences.chinese: 平原君听毛遂的话有些道理，就勉强同意带他去谈判。
“我的手表能照明，”茱莉亚毛遂自荐。

definition: Ling Xiangru (dates unknown, 3rd century BC), famous statesman of Zhao 趙國|赵国
Zhang Yi (-309 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Lord Menchang of Qi, Chancellor of Qi and of Wei during the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
Pang Juan (-342 BC), military leader and political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (425-221 BC)
Su Qin (340-284 BC), political strategist of the School of Diplomacy 縱橫家|纵横家[Zong4 heng2 jia1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏子, hero of book 晏子春秋
Yanzi (-c 500 BC), famous statesman from Qi of the Warring States, also known as 晏婴, hero of book 晏子春秋
King Huiwen of Zhao 趙國|赵国, reigned 298-266 BC during the Warring States Period
Prince Dan of Yan (-226 BC), commissioned the attempted assassination of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇) by Jing Ke 荆轲 in 227 BC
Prince Dan of Yan (-226 BC), commissioned the attempted assassination of King Ying Zheng of Qin 秦嬴政 (later the First Emperor 秦始皇) by Jing Ke 荆轲 in 227 BC

Wei Lao (c. 450 BC, dates of birth and death unknown), advisor to the first Qin emperor Qin Shihuang 秦始皇[Qin2 Shi3 huang2], possible author of the Wei Liaozi 尉繚子|尉缭子[Wei4 Liao2 zi5] text on military strategy
Duke Huan of Qi (reigned 685-643 BC), one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
King Xuan of Qi (reigned 342-324 BC)
Zhao, one of the seven states during the Warring States Period of Chinese history (475-220 BC)
Duke Mu of Qin, the first substantial king of Qin (ruled 659-621 BC), sometimes considered one of the Five Hegemons 春秋五霸
